item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: About This Blog
item.description:
Hello world!

Recently, I heard about Hugo and blogdown package which enables its users to create a website with R Markdown for free (and ad free as well). While I didn’t have any plan neither for blogging nor for having a personal website in near future, I was intrigued by the idea of building a website using R language. I also figured it would be nice and convenient to have everything related to work (e.g. docs, social networking accounts, experiences, blog) in one place in an organized fashion. So, I decided to give it a try in a rainy summer day, which perhaps isn’t a very helpful hint for Vancouverites as to which day it is. Well, it took longer than expected (as usual!), but I was able to publish this site in a relatively short amount of time. I believe it will be shorter for others who don’t spend much time playing with its features. At this point, my initial plan is to play further with blogdown and upload some content casually as I find time. As a former eager football blogs follower, I am aware of the fact that lifetime of blogs are short, and they tend to be forgotten.

If you are interested in this idea, I can list a couple of resources to get you started. Typically it assumes that you have some familiarity with R Studio and GitHub, but even if that’s not the case, it is easy to teach yourself using these resources and googling error codes you receive on R or GitHub. You may find this little bit time consuming (depending on error for sure), but it’s the best way to learn! The most exhaustive and comprehensive source is the book itself by creators of blogdown; “blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown” available at: https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown/ and the official Hugo guide available at: https://gohugo.io/getting-started/

If you don’t want to go through all the technicalities in this book, there are many useful posts from blogdown users regarding how to built one. They usually explain the process step by step. Here are some of them that I find useful, but know that there are so many others if any other information is needed. “Building a Blog with Blogdown and GitHub” by Tyler Clavelle available at: https://www.tylerclavelle.com/code/2017/blogdown/ “Start blogging in 5 minutes on Netlify with Hugo and blogdown” by dataatomic available at: https://dataatomic.com/r/deploy-your-blog-in-5-minutes/ “How to make your own website for free in an under an hour” by Dan Quintana available at: https://www.dsquintana.blog/free-website-in-r-easy/

There are basically two main options for hosting and deployment. It takes literally seconds using Netlify. All one has to do is drag and drop files. There are free and paid options available to users depending on expectations. Instead, I opted to use GitHub pages, which comes with multiple hosting methods. With some coding I find two branches method more convenient (and perhaps a more conventional way), but two repositories method also look like more straightforward to me. These are static site generators publish static files you push to your GitHub repository.

I think that’s long enough for the first post. If you have a question that I can be of any help, feel free to contact me.

item.title: Criminology blogs that inspired me
item.description:
As one make way through graduate school and the field, there is so much to explore. Classes, conferences, seminars, supervisors tend to be great sources but it is usually useful to go beyond them to get most out of it such as twitter, networking (and not being annoyed the word networking), extra curricular activities, hosting events, running a project etc. For me, criminology blogs functioned this purpose. Here is a neither comprehensive nor exhaustive list of these blogs that inspired me and provided most insight into academia;

https://rekadata.net/ by Dr. Reka Solymosi Lecturer in Quantitative Methods at the Department of Criminology at University of Manchester https://andrewpwheeler.com/ by Dr. Andrew P. Wheeler former Assistant Professor of Criminal Justice at University of Texas at Dallas https://martinxandresen.wordpress.com/ by Dr. Martin A Andresen (also my former supervisor!) Associate Professor at Griffith University https://www.jratcliffe.net/ by Dr. Jerry Ratcliffe who is a former British police officer and college professor https://joenedelec.wixsite.com/joenedelec by Dr. Joseph L. Nedelec Associate Professor of Criminal Justice at University of Cincinnati

If you feel like your blog can be part of the list above, please just let me know.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation
